speaker: Neil
text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Neil…

speaker: Alice
text: … and I'm Alice. Now Neil, how do you get to work?

speaker: Neil
text: I cycle.

speaker: Alice
text: I didn't know that! Somehow I hadn't imagined you as a cyclist. And where's all your bike gear?

speaker: Neil
text: Well, I sneak in the mornings, have a shower, and get changed. That's my bike in the corner over there.

speaker: foldaway
text: Oh, you've got a foldaway bike – which means it folds up so it's easy to carry or put away. Do you wear lycra, Neil?

speaker: Lycra
text: Yes, I do… it's very comfortable. I wear lycra as often as I can. Lycra by the way is a stretchy fabric used in tight-fitting sports clothes.

speaker: intrigued
text: Well, I'll have to see if I can catch you on your way into the building – I'm intrigued about this sporty Neil I didn't know about!

speaker: commuting
text: 'Intrigued' means to be very interested in something. Well, Alice, I'm flattered. And today's show is about commuting – or travelling between your home and your work. So how did you commute this morning, Alice?

speaker: Tube
text: I got the Tube – that's the subway system here in London, also known as the underground – and it was a nightmare. We stopped in a tunnel for so long that people started talking to each other.

speaker: Neil
text: And for those of you who aren't Londoners, that's unusual! Do you ever talk to people on the train?

speaker: Alice
text: No. People think you're crazy if you talk to strangers.

speaker: Neil
text: Well, maybe now's a good time to talk about today's quiz question, Alice. What question do you have for me?

speaker: Alice
text: Alright then. I know you like my questions, Neil. So here we go: What did the word 'commuter' originally describe? Was it someone who…

speaker: Alice
text: a) travelled with other people?

speaker: Alice
text: b) paid a reduced fare to travel?

speaker: Alice
text: Or c) travelled by train to work?

speaker: Neil
text: Oh, that's easy. I'm going to go for c) travelled by train to work.

speaker: Alice
text: Well, we'll find out later whether you're right or not. Now let's listen to a commuter in Nairobi who takes a matatu to get to work. These are minibuses used as shared taxis in East Africa. Can you spot a word that means being quick to notice things going on around you?

speaker: INSERT
text: Commuter, Nairobi, Kenya

speaker: INSERT
text: When I'm stuck in the matatu there is a lot of strange things happen around you, so you have to be alert in Nairobi. When you open… when you leave your window open somebody can run away with your belongings. You may be speaking… using the phone… somebody just snatch your phone… you may expect the unexpected!

speaker: alertbelongings
text: The word used by this commuter in Kenya is alert. And in these noisy, crowded buses you need to be alert in case someone runs away with your belongings – belongings are the things that you own.

speaker: snatch
text: Right. Somebody might snatch your phone – snatch means to take something quickly.

speaker: nap
text: Public transport in Nairobi sounds stressful! If I was taking the bus I'd want to have a nap – or short sleep.

speaker: Alice
text: Yes. Well, people have done research on commuting and stress levels – and interestingly women are more likely to experience stress during their journey than men.

speaker: Neil
text: Why's that?

speaker: Alice
text: Well, they're more likely to do something which is being called 'trip chaining' – where they make one or more stops on the way to work or going home – for example to drop off or pick up the kids from school – and this makes it more likely that something will go wrong with their journey.

speaker: traffic jam
text: Even if you aren't trip chaining it's no fun being stuck in a traffic jam – that's a large number of vehicles ​close together ​moving ​slowly – or being packed into a crowded train like sardines. Let's face it – travelling by car or by public transport can be really miserable!

speaker: Packed in like sardines
text: Yes. Packed in like sardines describes people standing so close together that they can't move – like fish in a can! So let's hear how longer commutes can affect your health from US researcher Christine Hoehner.

speaker: INSERT
text: Christine Hoehner, researcher at Washington University School of Medicine

speaker: INSERT
text: My study found that adults who commuted longer distances from home to work were less physically active, less physically fit, weighed more and had higher blood pressure than those people who had shorter commutes.

speaker: Neil
text: The American researcher must be talking about commuters who aren't engaged in active travel, mustn't she? Because if you cycle a longer distance then you're being more physically active.

speaker: Alice
text: I think you're right, for once, Neil!

speaker: Neil
text: Yeah.

speaker: Alice
text: And I'd better start going to the gym more. I don't like the sound of high blood pressure.

speaker: Neil
text: Why don't you hop on your bike, Alice? Then we can both wear lycra to work.

speaker: Alice
text: That's a fantastic idea, Neil! Moving on! Here's the answer to today's quiz question. I asked: What did the word 'commuter' originally describe? Was it someone who… a) travelled with other people? b) paid a reduced fare to travel? Or c) travelled by train to work?

speaker: Neil
text: And I said c) travelled by train to work. It must be right.

speaker: commuted
text: And you were wrong I'm afraid, Neil! It's b) someone who paid a reduced fare to travel. The Oxford Dictionary says the word 'commute' comes from Latin commutare, from com- 'altogether' + mutare 'to change'. The word was used in the US in the 1840s, when people paid a reduced or commuted fare to travel by rail from the suburbs into the city.
